Read MoreAll these are old tactics Mayawatii ji...Now time to think new statergy as all class of Indian people wants development and better future, so please try change your ideology and statergy to win people's heart...we wish you to change your ideology and emerge as tallest leader and be role model of every Indian women's rather than spending time in old caste based vote statergy. All the best!Som Patil

  

  She is also accused of following an autocratic lifestyle in the party as well as in the government in which both leaders and officials have to walk barefoot and she is considered as the last word.
  

  

  Her move of installing her own statues alongside Kanshi Ram is some of the memorials and describing herself as the "saviour of the underprivileged" also indicate her desire for reverence, her critics say.

link: BJP, allies make a clean sweep in Modi's Varanasi
article:
VARANASI: The BJP-led alliance swept all the eight assembly segments falling under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Lok Sabha constituency and this district.
  

  

  They retained three of the five seats in Modi's constituency Varanasi by comfortable margins and wrested the remaining two from the Samajwadi Party.
  

  

  In an electoral performance that may have surpassed all expectations, the alliance ended up winning three other assembly segments falling under Varanasi district, wresting two of these from the BSP and one from the Congress-SP combine.
  

  

  In the city, sitting MLA Ravindra Jaiswal retained Varanasi North, defeating former legislator and Congress candidate Abdul Samad Ansari by a margin of 46,000 votes.
  

  

  In Varanasi (South), debutante Neelkanth Tiwari retained the seat for the BJP, belying fears of an upset after the party denied ticket to seven-time MLA Shyamdeo Roy Chowdhury.
  

  

  Former MP and Congress candidate Rajesh Mishra tried to put up a fight but lost by a margin of 17,000 votes.
  

  

  Varanasi (Cantt) saw another successful debut, as Saurabh Srivastava won by a thumping margin of more than 60,000 votes to retain the seat that has been represented alternately by his late father Harish Chandra Srivastava and mother Jyotsna Srivastava.
  Burn Belly Fat In 7 Days (100% Results)SlimNowEnjoy the best of comedy with Biswa Mast Aadmi online!Amazon Prime VideoRecommended By Colombia

  

  The BJP sprang a surprise in the predominantly rural Rohaniya, where Modi had held his last election rally.
  

  

  With its prospects bolstered with a tie-up with Apna Dal (Soney Lal), the party won the Kurmi-dominated seat by a huge margin of 57,000 votes. This was a far cry from the party's position here five years ago when it had finished fourth.
  

  

  The BJP's ally Apna Dal (Soney Lal) tasted victory in Sevapuri, where it was the runner-up five years ago. The party's Neel Ratan Singh Patel defeated sitting SP MLA Surendra Singh Patel by 49,000 votes.
  

  

  Modi had camped in his constituency during the last three days of electioneering, held roadshows and addressed several rallies to reach out to voters in the district.

link: Bellwether Kasganj again got Uttar Pradesh polls right
article:
AGRA: Continuing with the bellwether trend, that whosoever party wins from Kasganj constituency forms the government in state, BJP Devendra Singh Rajput won with a huge margin of 52,030 votes, while his party made historical win with 312 seats.
  

  

  For the past 43 years, whichever party has won Kasganj - constituency number 100 in EC's list - has been able to form a government in the state. From Congress in 1974 to Samajwadi Party in 2012, all parties which eventually formed the government had conquered this seat, making it a bellwether constituency to watch.
  

  

  Contesting for the first time, Devendra Singh Rajput said, "Once again this constituency proved that road to Lucknow passes through Kasganj, though literally the district is slightly off the Agra-Lucknow national highway, BJP Devendra Singh Rajput win."
  

  

  "I have been active in the constituency as a social worker since a long time. Our party workers did a lot of hard work to make me win. The overwhelming support during campaigning has translated into votes and now we will take UP to new heights and work for the betterment of people," he said.
  

  

  With the Lodhs in majority in a constituency of 3.44 lakh voters, BJP's Devendra Singh Rajput, a Lodh, received 1,01,908 votes in his favour while his immediate rival SP's Hasrat Ullah Sherwani received only 49,878.
  

  

  In 1974, Manpal Singh won Kasganj on an Indian National Congress ticket which formed the government in the state. After the Emergency, Janata Party swept the state and country alike. That year, Netram Singh became the Janata Party's MLA from Kasganj.
  

  

  Six years later in 1980, the Congress was back in power, as was Manpal Singh in Kasganj. He won another election in 1985, as did the Congress in UP.
  

  

  In 1989, Mulayam Singh Yadav, a member of the then Janata Party, became the CM of the state. In Kasganj, the winning MLA, Goverdhan Singh, again belonged to Janata Party.
  

  

  Two years later, in 1991, the BJP made history by winning a clear majority in the state. Kalyan Singh, who was himself from Lodh community, became the chief minister, and Netram Singh was back as the Kasganj MLA on a BJP ticket.
  

  JaipurKurti Purple  White Printed Boat Neck Basic For WomenShopcluesKnow how much you need to save for the futureTomorrowMakersRecommended By Colombia

  In the Lodh-dominated area, Kalyan Singh himself contested from here and won the seat in 1993. Although the result was a hung assembly, Kalyan Singh's BJP was the single largest party. However, eventually an SP-BSP alliance formed the government in the state.
  

  

  BJP's Netram Singh was back here in 1996. Again, it was a hung assembly with the BJP as the single largest party. In 2002, the Samajwadi Party replaced the BJP as the single largest party, and SP's Manpal Singh was back.
  

  Latest CommentThere are three bell weather seats in UP: Sultanpur Sadar, Kasganj and I guess other is BijnorArvind Chauhan

  In 2007, Hasrat Ullah Sherwani of the Bahujan Samaj Party became the first Muslim MLA of Kasganj, and its first non-Lodh MLA in a long time. Mayawati was sworn in the CM with a clear majority in 2007.
  

  

  In 2012, it was the turn of the Muslim vote to be divided to help SP's Manpal Singh to win. The SP also won a clear majority in the state and Akhilesh Yadav became the chief minister.

link: BJP's huge win had polarisation recipe, too
article:
LUCKNOW: Success of the Bharatiya Janata Party in any election and especially in UP assembly poll without treading the polarisation path would be an incomplete story. Even though caste and high voltage campaigning may have played an important role, but the polarisation effect had its fair share with statements by Prime Minister Modi like "kabristaan-shamsaan," and using Mahant Yogi Adityanath to campaign extensively couple with low intensity communal incidents, too playing a role.
  

  

  West UP region of the state turning out to be a tried and tested laboratory for polarisation for the BJP ever since Muzaffarnagar riots in 2013 and a clean sweep from the region in 2014 Lok Sabha election, UP assembly poll would not have been different.
  

  

  However, more than the requirement of motormouths to tread the polarisation agenda, the BJP strategists went for an attacking strategy and showed no hitch in including many contentious issues like triple talaq, Ram temple, closure of abattoirs and anti-Romeo squad in the party's 'Lok Kalyan Sankalp Patra'.
  

  

  What the party needed was polarising figure to take up these issues in the West UP region. Unlike previous elections, when firebrand Gorakhpur MP Mahant Yogi Adityanath was utilised in a limited manner and mainly in eastern UP region, the party strategistst showed hitch this time in roping him in the sensitive West UP region. Yogi no wonder came true on the expectation of the BJP strategists with statements like situation in Kairana is like Jammu and Kashmir and raking up anti-Romeo squad.
  

  

  Next in the plan was UP BJP chief Keshav Prasad Maurya, who before joining the BJP, had been the Vishwa Hindu Parishad general secretary. Besides, helping the party in consolidating OBCs, Maurya's pro-Hindutva image also led to polarisation effect especially in the region.
  

  

  Both Yogi and Maurya together addressed over 30 rallies in West UP region alone.
  

  

  Prime Minister Narendra Modi himself a polarising figure before taking over as PM owing to Godhara riots, however, remained focused on political rhetorics than treading the communal line in his speeches until he remained in West UP region.
  

  

  However, after the first four phases, the PM came up statements like: If there is electricity during Ramadan then it must be provided during Diwali as well.
  

  

  Also, if there is a `kabristan' in the village, it should have a cremation ground too and added that the BJP believes in `Sabka saath, sabka vikas'.

  In between, the interviews of these leaders and statements on issues like triple talaq, closure of abattoirs and mention of the state government willing to become party for Muslim women on contentious triple talaq issues, if BJP comes in power, also lead to a divide among the voters.
  

  

  No wonder, the BJP had all the recipes ready to ensure the party comes to power. The party has won on 327 seats out of possible 403 seats.

link: Trampled twice in three years, RLD stares at political extinction
article:
MEERUT: With just 1.8% vote share, which translates to 15.45 lakh votes, and one seat in the 403-seat Uttar Pradesh assembly, the Rashtriya Lok Dal, which had been wiped out in the Lok Sabha elections of 2014, now stares at political extinction. Even in its stronghold of Baghpat district, of three seats it could manage to win just one, Chaprauli.
  

  

  The party had become steadily marginalized in the preceding elections, but had managed to hold on to its meager holdings in the past decade. In the 2002 assembly elections, 10 of its candidates had won, a tally which had been repeated in 2007. In 2012, 46 of its candidates had been in the fray but only nine had won, with a share of 2.33% of the total votes polled in the state.
  

  

  The party which looked certain to gain from apparent Jat anger against demonetisation and the central government's handling of the quota stir ended up losing its traditional voters' base once more.
  Earton WomenGirl Tan Sports Running ShoesShopcluesWondering if you need term insurance?MAX LIFE INSURANCERecommended By Colombia

  

  Organizational secretary of RLD for west UP, Rajkumar Sangwan, however, played down doomsday scenarios. "Saying that RLD is on the verge of extinction is wrong. In any case ours is a regional party mainly concentrated in the western UP belt. The poll result clearly reflects anger against the state government's policy of appeasement. The 'Yadavization' of government machinery coupled with lenient attitude towards crime particularly when committed by a particular community left the voter with no choice. What SP was to Muslims, BSP is to Dalits. So the electorate was left with no choice but to look towards a third alternative and they knew that RLD could not form a government on its own so they opted for BJP. We are only the victims of the criminalisation of politics done by SP and BSP."
  

  

  However, many in the RLD also felt that these elections were an opportunity lost. At a time when Jats, rattled by alleged state-sponsored violence on the community in Haryana during the quota stir, were looking to return to the RLD fold, the party could not capitalize on this issue. Nor could it work on the ill effects of demonetisation.
  Latest CommentIf the trend continues, the smaller groups like RLD will certainly become irrelevant in political arenaSandeep Rai

  

  "No matter how big or small an organization is, cadre has its own importance. Imagine what a party worker will feel when suddenly turncoats are invited and given tickets, while dedicated workers are ignored. At a time when Jats were willing to come back to their own party, our leaders were busy accommodating the newcomers. The result is in front of everyone," said a senior leader of western UP.
  

  

  However, some felt polarization has forever dented the prospects of RLD as a political party. "The Jat and Muslim combination was invincible till the Muzaffarnagar riots in 2013. It was because of this combination that (RLD supremo) Ajit Singh won six times for the Lok Sabha from Baghpat. Despite our best efforts we were not able to bridge the yawning gap created by the polarisation after the riots," said another leader.

link: Mayawati's jumbo jet couldn't take off with Dalit-Muslim formula
article:
LUCKNOW: Split in Muslim votes and Hindu consolidation in BJP's favour led to saffron surge in Uttar Pradesh assembly elections. Further, only 24 Muslim candidates could win elections. Results declared on Saturday also indicated that SP-Congress alliance was the first choice of Muslims despite Mayawati going all out to woo minority community.
  

  

  The BSP gave tickets to 99 Muslim candidates, highest ever by any mainstream party in UP since Independence. She also got Mukhtar Ansari's Quami Ekta Dal merged with the BSP and took support from Muslim-dominated Rashtriya Ulama Council. Several Muslim outfits and clerics also appealed in BSP's favour.
  

  

  However, results show that of 140 assembly constituencies where Muslim population is 20% or above, BJP won 109 and its ally Apna Dal 2, SP won 23 and its ally Congress 3, while BSP got 2. This pollsters said indicates Muslims chose SPCongress alliance over BSP.
  

  

  These 140 seats are said to be key in winning UP elections. In 2012, when SP came to power with majority, it won 72 at constituencies, BSP 27 seats, BJP 25, Congress 11, RLD 1 and others four. In 2007, BSP had swept 40% of the total seats and also won elections.
  

  

  Though Muslims constitute 19% of UP's population, this time there will be drastic drop in their representation in the state assembly with only 24 (6% of the total 403 seats) candidates from the community winning elections. In 2012, total 69 Muslim candidates (17.12%), highest since independence, reached assembly and in 2007, 46% (11.90%). In 2012 and 2007, caste equations dominated elections, besides other issues.
  Burn Belly Fat In 7 Days (100% Results)SlimNowRoam abroad freely with unlimited incomingAirtelRecommended By Colombia

  

  The lowest Muslim repre sentation in state assembly was 16 (4.05% of the total 419 seats then) in 1991when communal polarization took place due to Ram Temple movement and BJP came to power for the first time in the state with absolute majority. In 1993, in the elections held after Babri mosque demolition, only 24 (5.92%) Muslim candidates won.
  

  

  Analysts said that Muslim representation always comes down whenever there is pola rization on religious lives. In 1967 and 1969 when Gau Rakshan movement was at its peak, only 23 Muslims won elections on both occasions in UP.
  

  

  In this election, Mayawati's political engineering to bring together Dalit and Muslims failed as only five Muslim candidates out of total 99 fielded by the BSP, could win their seats. SP had given tickets to 57 Muslims, while Congress fielded 22 Muslims, of which only two won.
  

  

  In 2012, of 78 Muslim candidates fielded by SP, 43 won, while of 85 Muslims fielded by BSP , 16 won. Congress gave tickets to 62 Muslims, but four won. Two Muslims candidates won on Quami Ekta Dal ticket, one on Ittehad-E-Millat Council and three as Peace Party candidate. In 2007, SP fielded 58 Muslim candidates of which 21 won, BSP put up 61 of which 29 won, Congress fielded 49 but none won and RLD fielded three and all won.

link: 30 candidates lose their deposits in Gautam Budh Nagar constituencies
article:
NOIDA: As many as 30 candidates standing in the 17th assembly election of Uttar Pradesh from the three constituencies of Gautam Budh Nagar have lost their deposits for failing to secure even one-sixth of the total votes polled.
  

  

  These include the BSP candidate for Noida Ravikant Mishra, Congress candidate for Dadri Sameer Bhati, who was standing for the SP-Congress alliance from the constituency and SP's Jewar candidate Narendra Nagar.
  

  

  Only the closest competitors have managed to secure their deposit- an amount of Rs. 10, 000.
  

  

  According to the rules of the Election Commission of India, a security deposit has to be made by the candidate at the time of filing the nomination.
  

  

  The same goes to the treasury and is considered forfeited if the candidate fails to get a minimum of one-sixth of the total valid votes polled.
  

  Noida had a total of 14 candidates out of which 12 have failed to secure their deposit.
  United Bag Fast Trip Grey and Black Casual Backpack UBK344ShopcluesThis fruit will help you lose 30kg in 2 monthHealthreport24Recommended By Colombia

  

  A total of 254197 votes were polled in Noida out of which BJP candidate Pankaj Singh won 1, 62, 310 votes- 63.85 per cent of the total votes. Only, SP 's Sunil Choudhary has managed to save his deposit from Noida. Despite being the third highest gainer, BSP's Ravikant Mishra has failed to secure his deposit.
  

  

  In Dadri too, which saw a total of 14 candidates in fray, 12 failed to secure their deposit including Congress' Sameer Bhati, who was standing for the SP-Congress alliance. Only Satveer Gurjar of the BSP, who was the sitting candidate managed to save his deposit here. A total of 265099 votes were polled in Dadri, out of which BJP'S Tejpal Nagar got 141135 - 53.21 per cent of the total votes.
  Latest CommentCONgress won less seats than the number of children Lalu had!narasarao

  

  In a repeat-story Jewar too saw six candidates losing their deposit including SP's Narendra Nagar.
  

  

  211292 votes were polled in Jewar out of which BJP's Thakur Dhirendra Singh won a total of 102931 votes- 48.71 per cent of total votes. Only Vedram Bhati, who was the sitting candidate from the constituency managed to save his deposit.

link: Backing of clerics fails to draw Muslims towards BSP
article:
AGRA: How much weight did the word of Muslim clerics in support of the Bahujan Samaj Party carry this time? Negligible, it turns out. A large number of prominent clerics had thrown their weight behind the BSP and campaigned for the party, but it seems their endorsement did not work for the party which was hoping to sweep the elections with the support of Dalit and Muslim votes combined.
  

  

  Maulana Syed Mohammad Ashraf Kichachauvi of All India Ulema and Mashiakh Board, who had spoken in support of the BSP, told TOI it was a good sign that the community has risen above caste, creed and religion and voted for development, and he respected the mandate.
  

  

  "It is not that Muslims did not vote for the BSP. However, those votes could not transform into victory for the candidates. The vote share of BSP has not dwindled much this time and there is an urgent need to strengthen the party," Kichachauvi said. He also added that the community is hopeful of having an equal share in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'sabka saath, sabka vikaas' agenda.
  

  

  In a word of advice, Imran Hasan Siddiqui, president of Al Imam Welfare Association, Lucknow, another BSP supporter, said party supremo Mayawati failed to connect with voters the way PM Narendra Modi did through his roadshows.
  

  

  "Results are quite astonishing. The BSP could not make much use of the media to get exposure like the BJP or other parties did. Media coverage showed that the contest was only between the Samajwadi Party and the Bharatiya Janata Party. The Muslim voters were unable to decide who to vote - the SP or BSP. Besides, those who were traditional voters of the BSP also deserted the party," Siddiqui said. He added that a huge vacuum between voters and BSP leaders, including Mayawati, was formed and they failed to connect with the former. "With changing times, the BSP also needed to change its campaign strategy. Despite security threat, PM Modi conducted a massive road show in an open vehicle. It gave a huge message," he said.
  Earton WomenGirl Tan Sports Running ShoesShopcluesWondering if you need term insurance?MAX LIFE INSURANCERecommended By Colombia

  

  With the start of election campaigning, BSP had gone all out to woo Muslim voters with the help of clerics and various organisations. The BSP leadership was successful in roping in Rashtriya Ulema Council led by Maulana Aamir Rashadi Madani, Shahi Imam of Jama Masjid Maulana Ahmed Bukhari, noted Shia cleric and member of All India Muslim Personal Law Board Maulana Kalbe Jawwad and Maulana Syed Mohammad Ashraf Kichachauvi of Ulema and Mashiakh Board along with the AMU Students Union to extend its support towards the party.
  

  

  BSP chief Mayawati told minorities that voting for the SP-Congress alliance will go in vain and it will only help the BJP. A senior BSP leader, who did not wish to be named, reiterated allegations made by Mayawati that EVMs were tampered with. "How it is possible otherwise that BSP won those seats where Muslims were a majority and where BJP was not sure of winning?" he asked.
  

  

  Ashfaq Saifi, former national general secretary of BJP minority cell, said, "People have shut shops of these so-called Muslim leaders. The community has woken up and learnt to fight its own battle. They have understood that SP and BSP were playing the politics of fear. In three years of PM Modi's tenure, Muslims are not only safe and secure, but also getting better facilities and education."
  

  

  "A large number of Muslim women also voted for the BJP because of the party's stand on the issue of triple talaq. They might have told their husbands that they will vote for the SP and the BSP but in stead pressed the BJP button. Clerics have antagonised them after lending support to triple talaq," he added.

link: It is celebration time with kesariya gulaal for Muslims
article:
LUCKNOW: All roads in the city started leading to the BJP office in Hazratganj soon after trends started turning exit poll predictions true.
  

  

  Every corner of the party office was celebrating with followers throwing kesariya (saffron coloured) gulaal on each other. Several rounds of phoolon ki holi and bursting of crackers added diverse shades to the colours of victory. But few skull caps turned many heads as they roared har har modi.. ghar ghar modi.. and gaye gaye gaye gaye gaye akhilesh (against SP's slogan of jai jai jai jai jai akhilesh).
  

  

  One of them was Wakif Mahmood Rufi, who flared the party flag with full vigour. "I am here to tell everyone that Muslims are not averse to Modi or BJP," said the man who quit Samajwadi Party Mohalla Samiti after his party entered into a coalition with Congress Party. "SP was no longer safeguarding interests of the community," he reasoned.
  Travel Makes You Richer. Get Travel Insured!Bajaj Allianz Travel InsuranceAarohi Designer Gold Plated Australian Diamond Jewellery ComShopcluesRecommended By Colombia

  

  State president, minority wing, BJP, Haider Abbas Chand Bhai said that like all sections of society, Muslims also need development. "We have been befooled for long... caste or religion are a somethings one cannot choose or change. But improving one's quality of life through development is surely in our hands," he said.
  

  

  Party worker Zeeshan Mohammad, flared a lotus cutout like a child out of happiness. "I am into the business of flowers but I am so happy with the mandate that I have brought 51 kilos of rose, marigold and petunia to shower on our party president Keshav Maurya," said Zeeshan.
  

  

  The muslims workers and supporters had their set of expectations from the new government. One Peer Mohammad Khan from Chowk said, "I voted for sabka saath sabka vikaas. I wish the new CM integrates skill development of traditional artisans."
  

  

  Syed Tahir Raza Rizwi wants uplift of the community ."Sachar Committee report showed our educational backwardness... education can empower people and change their life for better," he said. When contacted, BJP Muslim Poster boy and party spokesperson, Mohsin Raza, said, "BJP against Muslims is a misnomer and all these happy faces prove it."

link: BJP out of woods in UP recording biggest win since Independence
article:
LUCKNOW: What sounded like political rhetoric on May 26, 2016, when Union home minister Rajnath said at a rally in Shahjahanjpur that BJP's "vanvas (exile)" in UP was about to get over, turned prophetic after 10 months on Saturday.
  

  

  There was no phenomenon like the 'Modi wave' of 2014 but BJP did it once again with UP's third biggest victory since Independence winning 300+ seats and decimating two regional giants, ahead the 2019 Lok Sabha poll.
  

  

  Congress had won 388 seats out of 430 in 1952 assembly election, followed by Janata Party winning 352 out of 425 possible seats in post-Emergency 1977 assembly election. The unprecedented and extraordinary win was not only a referendum on Modi's demonetisation drive, it also brought to fore BJP's social engineering skills in the caste-ridden politics of UP, which went hand-in-hand with polarisation. The huge victory of 324 seats out of 403 has the nod of the common man.
  

  

  The results are an indication of a new phenomenon that has emerged in this election—polarisation of the classes. While the pro-rich were heard protesting against the PM's move of demonetisation, the pro-poor were unnerved and instead, being happy over the fact that rich had to stand in queue.
  

  

  With a huge chunk of OBCs and Dalits falling in pro-poor category, their consolidation, especially of non-Yadav OBCs and non-Jatav Dalits through demonetisation coupled with projection of many OBC and Dalit leaders like UP BJP chief and Phulpur MP Keshav Prasad Maurya, besides former Leader of Opposition and a new entrant in BJP Swami Prasad Maurya and Agra MP Prof Ramshanker Katheria only helped the BJP further its cause.
  

  

  The shortfall in selection of candidates or weak candidates was taken care of by the Modi magic, which was not perceptible througout the election campaign but emerged as a strong point in favour of the BJP.
  

  

  Unlike in Bihar, however, BJP strategists and researchers maintained a balanced approach while utilising the PM services and his magic, thus limiting him to only 23 rallies across the state as compared to about 31 rallies in Bihar. His jibes on parties and leaders was not only well-researched, it delivered keeping in mind the region where the PM would address the gathering.
  

  

  At Kannauj, a region where family feud in the Yadav clan of Samajwadi Party could have divided the people, the PM reminded Akhilesh that his alliance partner Congress had once plotted an attack on his father Mulayam Singh Yadav in 1984.
  Topware (Jagdamba) insulated lunch box with 3 containersShopcluesWhy keep money idle when you can earn returns?FundsIndiaRecommended By Colombia

  

  BJP UP in charge Om Mathur said Modi once again emerged as their strongest point, though labour of party workers at ground level could not be overlooked.
  

  

  Unlike in the previous election, there was a balance on using polarising politics too with the likes of Mahant Yogi Adityanath and UP BJP chief Keshav Maurya being used maximum in West UP region, an area which has seen polarisation ever since Muzaffarnagar riots in 2013.
  Latest CommentBig slap to Mamata (west Bengal cm) who claimed lose of BJP IN UPRaj bhawal

  

  Though major losses were mainly from the Opposition benches, former chief of UP BJP Laxmikant Bajpayi's defeat in Meerut along with the drubbing of Mriganka Singh, daughter of Kairana MP Hukkum Singh at the hands of Rafique Ansari of Samajwadi Party and Nahid Hasan also of Samajwadi Party respectively, were the few major losses.
  

  

  With the huge win, however, has come an equally huge resposibility for the BJP leaders to deliver on their promises like the issue of triple talaq, closure of abattoirs, Ram temple, anti-Romeo squad, waiving of farmers' loan and clearing sugarcane dues of the farmers from state exchequer in 14 days as failing to do so would endanger their prospects in the Lok Sabha elections in 2019. So would be the selection of chief minister.

link: Owing to anti-incumbency, divided muslim vote, turncoats register wins in Dadri, Jewar
article:
DADRI/JEWAR: It was a day of the turncoats with both old and new managing to register wins in the election for the three constituencies of Gautam Budh Nagar.
  

  

  Anti-incumbency, lack of BSP connect at ground level and a divided Muslim vote led to a surprise win for the turncoat Thakur Dhirendra Singh who switched ranks from the Congress to the saffron party. Singh won with a margin of 22, 169 votes defeating the sitting candidate Vedram Bhati in the BSP stronghold.
  

  

  Jewar, which has seen a BSP candidate winning from the past three assembly elections, had the closest competition among all the three constituencies of Gautam Budh Nagar. While Noida and Dadri were clean sweeps, Jewar saw a tough fight which remained undecided till the 10th round of counting when both the BJP and BSP were at a difference of around 500 votes.
  

  

  Result was announced after the 25th round.
  

  

  Dadri has seen a return of the BJP after almost a decade when Nawab Singh Nagar was the constituency's MLA from October 1996 to May 2007.
  

  

  The latter was lobbying for a ticket from Dadri this time but was denied. Tejpal Nagar who had quit the BSP to join the BJP ahead of the 2014 general elections, was given a ticket from the party.
  

  

  Nagar's supporters had reached Delhi to protest against the candidature of Tejpal Nagar in the run up to the polls. Similarly, the BJP had faced protests for fielding Thakur Dhirendra Singh, an old Congressman who switched ranks shortly before the assembly polls on January 8.
  

  

  Even the losing candidates admitted that the Muslim vote was divided.
  

  

  Satveer Gurjar, who has been winning the Dadri seat for the past two assembly elections lost to BJP's Tejpal Nagar by 80, 140 votes.
  

  

  "Polarisation led to the votes going to Modi. They have sold fake dreams," Gurjar told TOI.
  

  

  However, he denied that the rural vote bank shifted to BJP.
  United Bag Travelon Spacious Small Travel Bag  - Large GreenShopcluesMistakes to avoid while purchasing insurance!TomorrowMakersRecommended By Colombia

  

  Vedram Bhati, who won the Jewar seat in 2012 defeating closest rival Thakur Dhirendra Singh, who was then standing for the Congress said that along with anti-incumbency, it was a weak candidate from the Gurjar community standing from the SP-Congress alliance that led to the votes falling in Dhirendra Singh's lap.
  

  

  "Had there been a strong candidate against me, votes would not have got transferred to the BJP," he said.
  

  

  The result suggested that even the traditional Congress votes went to Dhirendra Singh despite his switch.
  

  

  "I had an expectation that I will win with a margin over 50, 000 votes and will get 1, 25, 000 votes in total. But, votes have come from every village, every booth and I have received love from all the people and it is more than enough for me. The winning margin does not matter," Singh told TOI.

link: Backroom BJP man Sunil Bansal whose master strokes led to historic win
article:
LUCKNOW: Halfway through the poll campaign, Amit Shah had fondly called Sunil Bansal, a big factor in the 2014 win, the "hero of 2017 battle". A section of BJP leaders unhappy with him had been painting him as an arrogant man not ready to listen to others. Shah, no wonder had the eye to recognise Bansal's capabilities. With BJP getting absolute majority, the backroom boy of the UP BJP, Sunil Bansal is at the forefront.
  

  

  Just before Lok Sabha election, the Rashtriya Swayemsewak Sangh had decided to send Bansal to Uttar Pradesh to assist Shah who was then UP in charge. It was the first time both met each other, Bansal had once told TOI. The six months he spent during Lok Sabha election in UP gave him the experience of politics in the state. "This is one state where politics is in the air," he said, talking to TOI.
  

  

  Back in UP as organisation secretary, Bansal changed the social combination of the party. With Shah's support, Bansal managed to appoint an additional 1,000 office-bearers from booth to state level from OBCs, MBCs and Dalit caste. Instead of replacing OBCs and Dalits with upper caste office-bearers, he added them to the existing strength.
  

  

  He then selected around 150 workers to look after the BJP organisations' day-to-day functioning and ensured that 95% of his team comprised members of the state. "They were workers who had the zeal to work passionately for the party and were tech-savy too," Bansal said.
  

  

  After UP BJP registered over 2 crore members, the party's next task was to strengthen the booth. The BJP organisation secretary launched a drive of a sorts to form booth committees. Of the 1.47 lakh booths across the state, the BJP organisation managed to have effective committees on at least 1.08 lakh booths.
  Bonjour Mens Ankle Length Pack of 3 Pair Sports SocksShopcluesLady loses kgs in 1 week with  odd one trickManorama BlogRecommended By Colombia

  

  BJP also had to work hard on shedding its tag of being an urban party. It was Bansal's idea that the party contested panchayat elections. He faced resentment over the decision but with support of UP in charge Om Mathur and then UP BJP chief Laxmikant Bajpayi, BJP contested panchayat election and though it could win 327 seats, it remained runner-up in another 300-odd panchayats and lost in another over 300 panchayats by a meagre margin of around 100 votes. But ultimately, the party got over 1,000 rural leaders.
  

  

  BJP organisation wooed voters at micro level by organising youth, women and Dalit meets at vidhan sabha constituency level. Bansal ensured the party marked its presence on social media and facilitated monitoring of programmes being held througout the state on social media media. He directed his team to form various WhatsApp groups to ensure the progress of these programmes was updated.
  

  

  Bansal and his team meanwhile carried out a survey to ascertain possible candidates from each vidhan sabha constituency. Four different surveys were made about six months back, Bansal told TOI and added that candidates were selected after looking at the surveys.
  

  

  "We managed to ensure a social combination even in ticket distribution," shared Bansal, amid receiving greetings from all and sundry at the party office.

link: BSP draws blank in Maya's 'karmabhoomi' Bijnor
article:
BIJNOR: Widely known as the 'karmabhoomi' of BSP supremo Mayawati, no one understood the political demography of this district more than Behenji herself. It was in 1985 that BSP fielded her from Bijnor for Lok Sabha elections and again in 1989, when she was elected for the first time. For 10 years, she worked in the region and gained experience as a politician and mastered the art of caste politics. Even in the 2014 general elections, she started her campaign from Bijnor. While in 2007 UP polls, BSP won all the seven seats of this district, in 2012 also, despite anti-incumbency factor, her party won four out of eight assembly seats. But this time, the party has been routed. Out of eight seats in Bijnor district, six have gone to BJP and two to SP, leaving nothing for BSP. This could be a game changer for the party in coming times.
  

  

  After the shattering defeat of the party, BSP veterans are now crestfallen and say the Dalit-Muslim combination might no longer work. Talking to TOI, BSP's former mandal coordinator Sarjeet Singh said, "There are reasons for the defeat of the party not only in Bijnor but also in other parts of the state. First, we could not strike a balance among different communities. We had focused on Dalit-Muslim combination. In Bijnor, BSP fielded six Muslims out of eight seats, except two reserved seats, neglecting all other communities such as thakur, saini, jat, etc. BSP was completely trounced as all other communities united against the party and voted for BJP. Besides, a large number of Muslims joined the SP bandwagon. The Dalit-Muslim card proved a complete failure."
  

  

  Singh further stated, "The BSP leadership gives a cold shoulder to upcoming political stars in the party. Veterans and experienced leaders were sidelined before the polls. Former MLA Ashok Rana from Dhampur, MLA Tasleem Ahmed from Najibabad, Om Kumar from Nahtaur and former MLA Omwati Devi from Nagina contested the polls on BSP ticket in 2012, but in 2017 election, they fought from other party tickets and three of them — Om Kumar (BJP), Ashok Rana (BJP) and Tasleem Ahmed (SP) won. They had left the party as they felt ignored by the BSP leadership."
  SC0214G SPARX Men Canvas Shoes SM-214 OliveShopclues5 smart reasons to refinance your home loan.TomorrowMakersRecommended By Colombia

  

  Singh claimed that BSP leadership treated cadres with disdain and appreciated outsiders.
  

  

  Another veteran and former MLA Sheeshram Singh said, "There is no certainty that BSP leaders would get party tickets. The party leadership changes the ticket in last moment, keeping the aspirants in the dark."
  

  

  International president of Vishva Dalit Parishad, Bhupendra Pal Singh, said, "The BSP leadership indulges in marketing party tickets and give no monetary help to deserving candidates. Mayawati also failed to elicit help from the influential Muslim segment who can influence the voters."
  

  

  According to Nrapendra Deshwal, a resident of Bijnor, "We had great expectation from Mayawati but she failed on the issue of social engineering. This led to her failure."

link: Demonetisation not an issue in Agra, Firozabad; BJP makes impressive win
article:
AGRA: Despite losing their jobs after industries shut down due to cash crunch following demonetisation, industrial workers from Agra and Firozabad factories voted for BJP in the hope that a party, which is fighting corruption in a big way, will bring better days for them. The party won seven constituencies of the nine in Agra district and four of the five seats in Firozabad, putting to rest assumptions that these voters are angry with Modi over notebandi.
  

  

  Hundreds of glass, bangle, footwear and petha units were forced to shut down after the currency shortage, rendering tens of thousands of workers unemployed. Many workers believed the decision to demonetise high value notes was done to eliminate corruption and arrest those who had amassed wealth through illegal means. Babu Ram Nishankh, 82, leader of a workers' association at one of Firozabad's bangle industries, said, "Prime minister Narendra Modi's policy on notebandi struck a chord with workers who saw it as a move to bring equality among all sections of society. Despite facing criticism from his detractors, Modi kept speaking in favour of the poor during his rallies and this has borne results. People have reposed their faith in him and are hopeful that better days lie ahead for them."
  

  4-year-old needs an urgent Heart TransplantMilaapHome Is Where Your Story Begins. Insure Both!Bajaj Allianz Home InsuranceRecommended By Colombia

  According to latest reports, 90 out of 100 bangle factories had downed their shutters because of the cash crunch, and more than 1.35 lakh labourers were out of jobs since the demonetisation was announced in November last year. Workers, however, appear confident that if they can throw SP and BSP out of power in the state, they can also show the door to BJP if the party failed to fulfill its promises. "No doubt, there was anger against notebandi among workers. Things, however, improved later and the poor people were able to get their jobs back," Nishankh added.
  

  

  Airing similar sentiments, Puttu Singh, former state vice-president of Centre of Indian Trade Unions, said, "People have voted for change, thinking that a new government will work towards their betterment. Workers think if Modi ji can take a major decision to curb black money, it would not be too difficult for the PM to implement stringent labour laws in the industrial sector. Post-demonetisation, efforts are being made to open bank accounts of workers so that their wages go directly to these accounts."

  Puran Dawar, president of Agra Footwear Manufacturers and Exporters Chamber (AFMEC), said, "The election results have proved beyond doubt that demonetisation had no negative impact on people's minds. People from all strata of life came forward to vote for PM Modi not only in UP but in other states as well. Demonetisation was a revolutionary step by the central government to purge the system of corruption."
  

  

  Rajesh Aggarwal, secretary of Noori Darwaza Petha Union, said, "No doubt that our sector was badly hit by notebandi and workers had to sit idle at home, but it was a temporary phase. Today, things are back to normal. Workers saw voting for BJP as an attempt at indicting the corrupt."

link: Son of the toil gets Uttar right for BJP
article:
LUCKNOW: The hard lessons BJP learnt from its defeat in Bihar in 2015 were put to good use while planning its strategy for Uttar Pradesh 2017. This time round, BJP avoided the pitfalls of strident election rhetoric and steered clear of self-goals such as RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat's comments on quotas. Decisions on ticket distribution were carefully calibrated and local leaders were involved in every aspect of decision-making.
  

  

  BJP stuck to a fairly large bouquet of issues, ranging from Hindutva concerns like a ban on mechanised slaughterhouses and Romeo squads to welfare schemes such as farm loan waivers and a package for Bundelkhand. Apart from showcasing PM Narendra Modi as its poll mascot, the party cut its reliance on central leaders, and gave sufficient space to state leaders.
  

  

  Candidates were carefully chosen to reflect a caste balance spectrum with focus on non-Yadav OBCs. Three candidates were chosen from each constituency, and the MP had a major say . Candidates who had suffered successive defeats were not considered despite protests.State president Keshav Prasad Maurya, state general secretary (organisation) Shiv Kumar and national vice president Dinesh Sharma, were assigned the task of identifying candidates who were further vetted by BJP chief Amit Shah with poll managers like Sunil Bansal playing a key role.
  UTB015 Foursquare Double Pkt Expandable Travel BagShopcluesBurn 30 kgs in 7 weeks without liposuctionFit-Indian BlogRecommended By Colombia

  

  The campaign narrative had two distinct strands. While party seniors stuck to the development agenda, local functionaries focused on micro issues to strike a chord with the voters. BJP's cause received a boost when the Dayashankar Singh-Swati Singh episode happened. After making slanderous remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, BJP member Dayashankar was sacked as state general secretary. But the equally offensive diatribe by BSP functionaries against Dayashankar's wife Swati polarised upper castes against Mayawati.
  

  

  The election results show a rare convergence of Brahmins and Thakurs, who together constitute around 19% of voters. Firebrand Hindutva speaker Yogi Adityanath criss-crossed the state. Sensing legal hurdles, the party was pragmatic and didn't make fresh promises on the Ram temple and reiterated its construction through Constitutional means.
  Top CommentOutsider wins the hearts, as insider lost faith of the people.Mpraomokkapati

  

  Unlike Bihar, state leaders led from the front during 'parivartan' rallies with 'nukkad' meetings and direct interaction with the people as the highlights. Modi and Shah were reserved for the bigger occasions.
  

  

  "We had direct connect with more than two crore people across the state after covering 17,000km during the parivartan yatra," said Maurya.

link: Parivar pips Pari-war, Tipu has battles ahead
article:
LUCKNOW: Kaam nahi, karnaame bolte hain," PM Narendra Modi's counter-offensive against UP chief minister Akhilesh Yadav's high-voltage campaign of "Kaam bolta hai", worked wonders for the saffron outfit in the UP polls.
  

  

  The SP's road ahead now appears difficult; among its primary challenges are keeping the clan war in the Yadav family from re-erupting and addressing the resentment among senior members who have been defeated.
  

  

  The result can be seen as a verdict on the SP government, which was mired in controversies involving corruption, lawlessness and nepotism, and shows that the people were not taken in by the SP's attempt to hard-sell Akhilesh as a clean and development-oriented leader.
  

  

  The size of the BJP's victory demonstrates that the ground realities highlighted by it hurt the young CM: poor law and order, a free run to the `bhu' (land) mafias and preferential recruitment.UP's voters reposed faith in Modi's promise to end the "karobaar of bahubalis" when BJP came to power.
  

  

  "The results show that the UP CM's good image was diluted by controversies related to land grabbing, nepotism in government recruitment and the impression of lawlessness that prevailed for a large part of his tenure. The party failed to convince voters," said a political analyst. It seems the SP's "thuggish" image affected the party , and Akhilesh's laudable initiatives, such as the `ambulance sewa' and an emergency crime helpline, came too late for any meaningful impact.
  United Bag Fast Trip Grey and Black Casual Backpack UBK344ShopcluesGirl burns 15 kg per month with this productHealthreport24Recommended By Colombia

  

  The SP narrative, like the one put forth by its Gorakhpur district chief, Prahlad Yadav, that "SaPa ne goondo ko kinara kar liya hai. Sab ab jail mein sarh rahe hain (SP has thrown anti-social ele ments into jail)", failed to convince people.
  

  

  Even younger voters seem to have chosen Mod over the "UP ke ladke" as Modi's aggressive pitch against the Samajwad Party government's al leged discrimination in recruitment processes res onated among them.
  Top CommentBaap aur beta thought UP is their back yard.narasarao

  

  The SP tried to counter BJP's promise to set up "anti-Romeo squads near colleges to ensure the safety of girls but Dimple Yadav's reply that the BJP promise was an attempt to go after the freedom women enjoy in a college or university environment, and that the squads would become "anti Romeo-Juliet squads" that harass couples, went unheeded. And BJP managed to cash in on the insecurity among young women due to poor law and order.
  

  

  The big and immediate challenge SP faces is the nomination of the Leader of the Opposition in the state assembly .Apart from that, party insiders said the huge defeat may even revive the intrafamily struggle.

link: How BJP beat Maya, Mulayam at their caste card game
article:
LUCKNOW: Known so far for playing mandir, polarisation and development cards and even after getting branded as a party of upper castes and baniyas, BJP this time used the caste formula, a forte of Mulayam and Mayawati that kept the two regional parties in power for around 15 years.
  

  

  From selection of candidates to anointing Keshav Maurya state president a year ahead of polls, welcoming strong OBC leaders like former Leader of Opposition Swami Prasad Maurya from other political parties and targeting sections like non-Yadav, OBCs & non-Jatav Dalits, the BJP this time succeeded in trumping SP and BSP on their home turf by cracking the caste code.
  

  

  Expanding support base among non-Yadav OBCs and non-Jatav Dalits was first made under Kalyan Singh and the outreach, helped by the Ram Mandir campaign, paid rich dividends too. In 1991, BJP led by Kalyan Singh rode to power with 221 seats, won 177 in 1993 and bagged 174 seats in 1996.
  

  

  But by late 1990s, it was abandoned after Kalyan Singh left the BJP and leaders like Rajnath Singh, Kalraj Misra, Kesarinath Tripathi took centrestage. By 2002, the BJP could win only 88 seats. That was the time Mulayam Singh-led Samajwadi Party with 143 seats and Mayawati-led Bahujan Samaj Party with 98 seats emerged as two principal players.
  

  

  The first attempt to revive the social coalition was made by Amit Shah who paid heed to Kalyan Singh's suggestions. Modi's own appeal as the first "backward' to have made it to the PMO on his own steam was another factor. During Lok Sabha election, Amit Shah came to UP as its in charge.
  

  

  The first sign of BJP shifting back to wooing non-Yadav OBCs was evident when it fielded 25 OBCs, 17 Brahmins, 14 Thakurs, 17 Dalits, 3 Vaishays and one Pasi and Bhumihar each, while tickets for two seats were given to Apna Dal. A total 27 tickets were given to OBC candidates including the Apna Dal.
  

  

  BJP ended up making a record of sorts with party and alliance candidates together winning 73 out of possible 80 seats. With over two years left for assembly election, national BJP chief BJP Rajnath Singh, who became Union Home Minister in Modi cabinet, was replaced with Amit Shah as the party chief. Like Lok Sabha election, the BJP had set goal of winning UP assembly election and Shah knew that without wooing non-Yadav and non-Jatav Dalits, it would not be possible.
  

  

  They began wooing non-Yadav OBCs early. In March 2015, Shah wasted no time in accepting invitation from Anil Rajbhar, then a SP leader, to address a rally. "Today is the beginning of bringing backward castes and other castes under a single umbrella. This is necessary because despite reservation policy, only one caste (Yadavs) is getting all benefits meant for all Backward Castes," Shah had said, addressing the 'Adhikar Paao Maharally' on March 23 in Varanasi. Shah inducted over 15,000 members of the Rajbhar community into the BJP.
  

  

  Shah went to Bahraich to garland the statue of Suheldev Pasi, a king who stopped Salar Jung's accession. Shah continued with such moves quite regularly. In the same way, the BJP leadership also focussed on non-Jatav Dalits. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Ravidas Temple in Varanasi was seen as one such move.
  

  

  In the meantime, the party strategists also were on job not only to woo prominent OBC leaders into the party fold but also to project OBC leadership of the BJP. No wonder, appointment of Phoolpur MP Keshav Prasad Maurya as UP BJP chief was one such move. The attempt was to woo about 8% of Kushwaha, Maurya, Shakya and Saini community.
  Hmt Ladies Designer Wrist WatchShopcluesKnow the first step of financial planningMAX LIFE INSURANCERecommended By Colombia

  

  Many such decisions mobilised OBCs. Demonetisation decision by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, against Opposition's claims of angering the middle class, polarised the pro-poor, who also belong largely to OBC and Dalit communities, and further united them against the pro-rich.
  

  

  When it came to ticket distribution, the BJP leadership was generous to OBCs who got over 40% tickets out of 403. Party strategists like UP in charge Om Mathur and organisation secretary Sunil Bansal further ensured that OBC leaders like Keshav Maurya, Swami Prasad Maurya, Swatantra Deo Singh and others are utilised maximum and address rallies in a bid to woo OBC voters.
  

  

  According to a rough estimate, UP BJP chief Keshav Maurya addressed around 200 rallies across the state.
  

  

  It is, thus, not surprising that BJP won around 290 seats out of 403. Next goal beng now 2019 Lok Sabha election, it would be interesting to see whether the CM is from OBC or Dalit category.

link: Urban voters lift BJP prospects
article:
GHAZIABAD: The seats in Ghaziabad that have primarily an urban voter base yielded good dividends to the BJP in the latest polls. Though the BJP won hands down in all five seats of the district, margins of victory were higher in urban seats compared to those seats where the voter base was rural. This was the main reason for the highest victory margins in Sahibabad and Muradnagar, which have primarily urban voters.
  

  

  In Sahibabad assembly seat, which includes the urban areas of Indirapuram, Vaishali, Vasundhara and Kaushambi, BJP candidate Sunil Sharma trounced his nearest rival Amarpal Sharma by a margin of over 1.5 lakh votes. BJP has won the seat despite the fact that Amarpal Sharma has a huge vote bank in Khoda colony which is located on the borders of Delhi.
  

  Travel Makes You Richer. Get Travel Insured!Bajaj Allianz Travel InsuranceAarohi Designer Gold Plated Australian Diamond Jewellery ComShopcluesRecommended By Colombia

  The second highest margin of victory for the BJP in the district has been in Muradnagar seat. The two upscale areas of the district, Kavi Nagar and Raj Nagar, are in Muradnagar. Here, BJP's Ajit Pal Tyagi trounced his nearest rival, Sudhan Rawat of the BSP, by a margin of over 89,000 votes. Congress veteran Surendra Prakash Goel, who also contested from Muradnagar, bagged just 49,000 votes.
  

  

  "It is the mandate of the people and we respect it. However, polarisation tactics was used by the BJP to woo voters which resulted in the mandate going in their favour," Ghaziabad district Congress president Harendra Kasana told TOI.
  

  

  The Ghaziabad assembly constituency also contains a sizeable section of urban population in areas like Nehru Nagar, Model Town, Rakesh Marg and Patel Nagar. The string of massive victory margins continued in Ghaziabad seat too. The BJP candidate from Ghaziabad, Atul Garg, won the seat by trouncing his nearest rival, Suresh Bansal of the BSP, by a margin of over 70,000 votes.
  

  

  The lowest margin of victory for the BJP has been recorded in Loni assembly seat which has a primarily rural voter base. Nand Kishor Gujjar of the BJP has won the Loni seat by defeating his closes rival Zakir Ali of the BSP by nearly 43,000 votes.

link: Lotus bloom steals life at Samajwadi Party office
article:
LUCKNOW: A simple presser thrown by Samajwadi Party used to be enough to clog the Vikramaditya Marg. But the typical hullaballoo around the ruling party went missing here on Saturday as Modi brigade trampled the 'UP ke ladke'.
  

  

  At around 9 am, when the first set of trends for the state came in, several khadi-clad supporters, dawning the Samajwadi 'topi', were seen watching election results on a LED TV fitted van.
  Earton WomenGirl Pink Sneaker Casual ShoesShopcluesUse this weird fruit to lose 30kg in 2 monthsHealthreport24Recommended By Colombia

  

  In no time, several media persons joined them and started giving live PTC (piece to camera). But the road was wearing a deserted look. SUVs came in, halted for a few seconds to assess the situation and then went away. Some even got down and walked up to the party office gate, but returned in no time. Policemen deployed there were quick to conclude the changing times. "Parivartan ki bela hai..." remarked one of them.
  

  

  The fragrance of incense sticks and 'havan samagri' drew the nose and took it to a small Hanuman Temple, about 50 metres away from the SP office. A party worker was quietly submitting 'ahutis' into the fire amidst the echo of Sundar Kaand (a religious chapter on the deity) paath. Photographs of Akhilesh Bhaiya and Dimple Bhabhi were placed before the deity to invoke his blessings. "I am praying for our party's victory," said the devotee Ram Avtaar Yadav, a native of Azamgarh.
  

  

  Asked if he had seen the trends indicating BJP's landslide victory in UP, he said, "Yes I have, but they are trends. I will not lose hope till the results are declared." By 1 pm, trends grew stronger and SP's nosedive became a fact which disheartened a handful of supporters who were hoping against hope. In the evening, CM Akhilesh Yadav invited reporters to his official residence 5 Kalidas Marg for one last time.
  

  

  As Akhilesh told the media that he had accepted the verdict, a pall of gloom descended on the party office. An hour later, drizzle made a few pedestrians find shade near the office. One of them Mohan Kumar remarked, "Indra dev bhi khush hain kamal ke khilne se. (Even the rain god is happy with the blooming of lotus)."

link: 'Handed' the lotus, Amethi, Rae Bareli turn saffron
article:
LUCKNOW: The BJP has invaded the Gandhi bastions and planted the lotus, quite firmly, in the hands of Amethi and Rae Bareli folk. Saturday's sweeping mandate for BJP resulted in the complete decimation of Congress in Rahul Gandhi's constituency Amethi. From a naught in 2012, the BJP has made a giant leap, winning six out of 10 seats in the twin Gandhi pocket borough.
  Earton WomenGirl Tan Sports Running ShoesShopcluesWondering if you need term insurance?MAX LIFE INSURANCERecommended By Colombia

  

  While the Amethi seat was wrested out of SP minister Gayatri Prajapati's stronghold and handed over to BJP's 'Rani' Garima Sinh, the party has also lost the two seats it has won here in 2012 -Jagdishpur and Tiloi. This time, though, while four of the five assembly constituencies were lapped up by the BJP, SP's incumbent MLA Rakesh Pratap Singh will get another term in the UP assembly as a SP nominee. The Congress did only marginally better in Rae Bareli, the neighbouring constituency that Congress president Sonia Gandhi has held since 1998.
  

  

  Here, the party debuted on the Rae Bareli Sadar and Harchandpur seats, and conceded Unchahar to alliance partner SP, and the remaining two, Sareni and Bachhrawan, to the BJP.
  

  

  Alliance leaders attribute the performance to the internal troubles over seat-sharing. Congress leaders -read Priyanka Gandhi Vadra -was keen to see the Congress contest on all 10 seats in Amethi and Rae Bareli.
  

  

  Even though this appeared a bad electoral decision -considering Congress had only won two of 10 in 2012 -Congress pressed for total control over all seats in twin VIP zones. Eventually, the SP conceded ground on seven seats, four of which ended up seeing a contest between the SP and Congress, in addition to the common enemy, BJP.

link: Who did Kairana throw out? Exodus author Hukum Singh's daughter
article:
MEERUT: In the end, the wheel turned full circle for BJP MP Hukum Singh. The author of the Kairana 'exodus' theory on Saturday found that it was his daughter and party candidate Mriganka Singh that voters had thrown out, so to speak, from the constituency.
  

  

  Kairana, a restive west UP town, figured prominently in political speeches of BJP leaders as they repeated Hukum Singh's contention that there had been a consistent 'exodus' of Hindus from the place. Party president Amit Shah, Gorakhpur MP Yogi Adityanath and a host of others promised to stop the "injustice" if the party came to power. Ironically, even as the BJP swept the entire "riot belt" of west UP, Kairana slipped out of its hands.
  

  

  Mriganka Singh, the 57-year-old political novice that the BJP put up from Kairana, lost to Nahid Hasan of SP, who polled 98,830 votes against her 77,668 votes.
  Travel Makes You Richer. Get Travel Insured!Bajaj Allianz Travel InsuranceAarohi Designer Gold Plated Australian Diamond Jewellery ComShopcluesRecommended By Colombia

  

  Kairana had become a poll issue months before the actual declaration of election dates and was aggressively highlighted by the BJP, with the entire narrative being spearheaded by Hukum Singh himself.
  

  

  But there was a twist in the tale waiting for Hukum Singh. The moment he managed to hoist his daughter up as the candidate from the seat, the party split down the middle, with Anil Kumar, a party veteran from the region, raising the banner of revolt. He later joined RLD along with his supporters and was rewarded with a ticket by Ajit Singh. Although Anil Singh polled just 19,992 votes, the internal party friction sealed the fate of the BJP in the constituency.
  Latest Commentinternal party squabbles cost BJP dearly in its 'exodus'labSandeep Rai

  

  Speaking to TOI, Anil Kumar said, "I have not won the election but at least I have been able to downsize the ego of the so called tallest star campaigner of BJP in this region, who despite the massive saffron wave in the state could not even manage a win for his own daughter. We could have won here by a huge margin of more than 30,000."
  

  

  All through the day, Hukum Singh kept saying that his daughter would win the seat but after declaration of results refused to talk to the media.

link: Jaipur man who ran BJP's war room in UP
article:
LUCKNOW: Halfway through the poll campaign, Amit Shah had fondly called Sunil Bansal the "hero of the 2017 battle". And in the end, the 47-year-old backroom boy, did prove his worth, despite a section of the BJP ganging up against him and projecting him as an arrogant man who does not listen to others.
  

  

  Just before the 2014 Lok Sabha election, the RSS decided to send Bansal, who had once been ABVP's general secretary in Jaipur, to Uttar Pradesh to assist Shah, who was then the UP in-charge. It was the first time both met.The six months he spent during the Lok Sabha elections in UP gave him the right experience. "This is one state where politics is in the air," he said.
  

  

  Back in UP as organisation secretary this time, Bansal changed the social combination of the party. With Shah's support, Bansal managed to appoint an additional 1,000 office-bearers from booth to state level from OBCs, MBCs and dalit caste.Instead of replacing OBCs and dalits with upper-caste office-bearers, he added them to the existing strength.
  UTB015 Foursquare Double Pkt Expandable Travel BagShopcluesThis fruit will help you lose 30kg in 2 monthHealthreport24Recommended By Colombia

  

  He then selected around 150 workers to look after BJP's day-to-day functioning and ensured that 95% of his team comprised members of the state. "They were workers who had the zeal to work passionately for the party and were tech-savvy , too," Bansal said.
  

  

  After UP BJP registered over two crore members, the party's next task was to strengthen the booth. Bansal then launched a drive to form booth committees. Of the 1.47 lakh booths across the state, BJP managed to have effective committees on at least 1.08 lakh booths. BJP also had to work hard on shedding its 'urban party' tag. It was Bansal's idea that the party contest panchayat elections. He faced resentment over the decision but with support of UP in-charge Om Mathur, BJP contested panchayat elections and won 327 seats.
  

  

  The BJP wooed voters at the micro level by organising youth, women and dalit meets. Bansal ensured the party marked its presence on social media and facilitated monitoring of programmes being held throughout the state on social media.
  

  

  Bansal and his team carried out a survey to ascertain possible candidates from each assembly constituency . Four different surveys were carried out about six months back, Bansal told TOI and added that candidates were selected after looking at the surveys.

link: UP and away: Narendra Modi's approach touches the poor
article:
LUCKNOW: Modi hit the campaign trail in UP in top gear. From Mirzapur to Bharaich and Jalaun to Lucknow, through the 23 rallies, his message was the same: trust me, vote for me, I get the job done. Modi went into the campaign lumbered with the liability of demonetisation but turned it into a populist vote winner by emphasising that it was part of his anti-corruption, anti-rich campaign. From Hindu Hriday Samrat of Gujarat to Development Man in 2014, UP 2017 saw Modi re-invent himself as pro-poor welfarist. In Indira Gandhi style, Modi was the PM seeking to win a state election on the basis of his own persona, not through state leaders.
  

  

  "One party wants to save its family, the other, its party; but only one party wants to save UP," he said in Lucknow, "our fight against corruption and black money won't stop." "Jo upar the wo neeche aa gaye hain," said a Jayapur local. Said a boat man in Varanasi: "We had no problems with notebandi because we had no big notes. Jinke paas bade note the, unko problem hua."
  Watch blockbuster film Bahubali online on Amazon Prime VideoAmazon Prime VideoBest performing mutual funds to invest inFundsIndiaRecommended By Colombia

  

  Reaching directly across to the voter, promising them a war against the rich, UP 2017 evoked Indira Gandhi's bank nationalisation moment in 1969 when putting the rich in their place had become a vote-winner with the poor. Modi was able to stand forth as a champion of the poor. "The suit boot ki sarkar charge did hit us," said a BJP member, adding, "We went out of our way to change our image from pro-Ambani and Adani to create a coalition of the poor."
  

  

  UP also saw a consolidation of the "sab jaat versus teen jaat", BJP's Kalyan Singh-style social engineering of 1991reinvented for 2017. This resulted in most backward castes, non-Yadav OBCs and non-Jatav dalits all clustering with BJP against the three castes -Jatavs, Yadavs and Muslims, represented by BSP , SP and Congress, who were pushed to become only subcaste fronts. Shedding its Brahmin-bania image, BJP created a wide social coalition of poor and backwards. It gave 119 seats to non-Yadav OBCs such as Rajbhars, Khushwahas and Mauryas. BJP even struck an alliance with the littleknown Suheldev Bhartiya Samaj Party -a party of Rajbhars -and gave them eight tickets.They also gave 69 tickets to non-Jatav dalits, such as Dhobis and Khatiks. The Ujwala gas scheme, soil card, rural housing and toilet construction schemes led to BJP making inroads among the poor and Modi being projected as the guardian of the garib.
  Top CommentFor a long time in our great nation, no leader has touched the heart cords of our people as much as Modi. His sincerity, zeal and hard-working ability in pursuing his every endeavor is amazing. No wo... Read MoreFor a long time in our great nation, no leader has touched the heart cords of our people as much as Modi. His sincerity, zeal and hard-working ability in pursuing his every endeavor is amazing. No wonder the goddess of success has been blessing him.Ethical Athiest

  

  In Maharajganj, he pitched his Harvard-vshard work line when GDP data showed demonsitisation had not taken a toll on growth. "On the one hand, there are those who talk of what people at Harvard say, and on the other is a poor man's son who through his hard work is trying to improve the economy." "Modi is in every heart in UP," said Dinesh Tiwari, a taxi driver, adding, "He is someone like us."
  

  

  Modi's speeches were full of droll black comedy; colourful, often crass, language; and mimicry, theatrically delivered with dramatic pauses. It's a performance that the droning voice of Mayawati dully reading out her speeches can hardly match. In Meerut, he spoke of the other parties as "SCAM"; in Bharaich, he countered Akhilesh by yelling that the humble donkey was a source of inspiration; in Fatehpur, he made the shamshan-kabristan speech, showing that at heart he remains a Hindu nationalist, a revelation that touched a chord across traditional UP. A populist lone crusader against corruption and a man of the masses who had risen from humble origins was the Modi identity on offer in 2017: Hindu hriday samrat combined with pro-poor populism harked back to the Indira Gandhi persona of patriotic heroine of the people.

link: Akhilesh Yadav loses his throne, can he remain sultan of SP?
article:
LUCKNOW: The years when Mulayam Singh Yadav was in charge of Uttar Pradesh always seemed to reinforce the feeling that Netaji's rule meant 'Yadav raj', cronyism and lawlessness. Son Akhilesh attempted to correct this image deficit by taking on the old guard and its "old politics" and by softening the party's caste dependency. But Saturday showed these up as politically inadequate.
  Zeven MenS Blue Cricket Lace-Up Shoes ZFFW133M3BAShopcluesDelicious way of dropping 8 kilos in 14 daysHealthreport24Recommended By Colombia

  

  The 2017 mandate+
  has created doubts about the 43-year-old's leadership and political acumen. With no returns to show for the high-profile internecine feud or for
  embracing the Congress+
  , Akhilesh is set to face serious questions, the challenge compounded by the fact that the poll defeat will embolden inhouse rivals like uncle Shivpal. Already, Shivpal,
  ousted as state party president+
  by his nephew, has described the party's defeat as a mandate against the "arrogance" of the party leadership.
  

  

  The post-defeat years will test Akhilesh as a politician. The chief ministership came on a platter after the 2012 victory under Mulayam's leadership. Now, he is on his own. And the challenges are massive, not the least the return to pole position of BJP that adroitly melded Mandal and Kamandal into a winning formula. In light of this, the traditional rivalry against BSP is a smaller challenge.
  

  

  Akhilesh's decision on an alliance with the Congress is being closely assessed. His father had openly expressed his disapproval on the move, as had uncle Shivpal. As an example of the sort of questioning his decisions will face in the coming days, Ravidas Mehrotra, the party candidate from Lucknow Central, complained, "I would have won the election, but for the Congress. Its candidate refused to withdraw despite our alliance and ensured my defeat."
  

  

  Akhilesh has been decisive in opting for a new political agenda for SP. He tried to ease the caste identity of his father's platform, preferred to contest on the development plank, sewed up an alliance with the Congress, even threw his wife Dimple into the battle as a star campaigner -all against the wisdom of his anti-Congress father who always banked on social engineering and never on a woman family member to garner votes. And that is a page, many believe, which cannot be turned back. So, Akhilesh has his task cut out. And the urgency could not be greater. He has just two years before the 2019 general elections to come up with a party idiom that can prove competitive in the BJP era.

link: Lalu Prasad supports Mayawati's allegation of EVM tampering in UP
article:
PATNA: RJD President Lalu Prasad on Saturaday supported BSP chief Mayawati's allegations that EVMs were tampered in Uttar Pradesh polls and demanded a probe by the Election Commission.
  

  

  "What Mayawatiji is saying should definately be probed by the Election Commission," Prasad told reporters.
  

  

  "It's known that Gujarat is the hub of EVM manufacturing, hence tampering of EVMs cannot be ruled out.

  "We had complained to the EC about this in the past and also held demonstrations on the issue. The EC had assured that mock polls would be conducted in every booth before the actual polling in which representatives of all parties could check whether the EVMs were working properly or not," the RJD chief said in support of demand for probe.
  

  

  "I don't know whether mock polls were held in UP or not," Prasad, who had campaigned in favour of Samajwadi Party said.
